title: Scan Signature
description:
A packet capture shows the following pattern from source IP 10.10.14.5:

SRC:10.10.14.5 → DST:192.168.1.10 TCP SYN → port 21
SRC:192.168.1.10 → DST:10.10.14.5 TCP RST,ACK ← port 21
SRC:10.10.14.5 → DST:192.168.1.10 TCP SYN → port 22
SRC:192.168.1.10 → DST:10.10.14.5 TCP SYN,ACK ← port 22
SRC:10.10.14.5 → DST:192.168.1.10 TCP RST → port 22
SRC:10.10.14.5 → DST:192.168.1.10 TCP SYN → port 23
SRC:192.168.1.10 → DST:10.10.14.5 TCP RST,ACK ← port 23

This is a specific type of port scan. The scanner sends SYN, and if it gets SYN-ACK back, it sends RST instead of completing the handshake.

What is this scan type called?

Submit as: flag{scan_name} (lowercase, two words with underscore)
hints: It never completes the three-way handshake
In nmap, this is the default scan type: nmap -sS
